IDBObjectStore.summary: The IDBObjectStore interface of the IndexedDB API represents an object store in a database. Records within an object store are sorted according to their keys. This sorting enables fast insertion, look-up, and ordered retrieval.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreGetKey.summary:
The getKey() method of the
interface returns an object,
and, in a separate thread, returns the key selected by the specified query. This is
for retrieving specific records from an object store.

remarks.para:
If a key is successfully found, then a structured clone of it is created and set as the
result of the request object.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreGetKey.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is the key for the first record matching the given key or key range.

IDBObjectStoreGetAll.summary:
The getAll() method of the
interface returns an object
containing all objects in the object store matching the specified parameter or all
objects in the store if no parameters are given.

remarks.para:
If a value is successfully found, then a structured clone of it is created and set as
the result of the request object.
This method produces the same result for:
To tell these situations apart, you either call

IDBObjectStoreGetAll.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is an {{jsxref("Array")}} of the values of all records matching the given query, up to the value of count, if count was supplied.

IDBObjectStoreAdd.summary: The add() method of the interface returns an object, and, in a separate thread, creates a structured clone of the value, and stores the cloned value in the object store. This is for adding new records to an object store.

remarks.para:
To determine if the add operation has completed successfully, listen for the
transaction's complete event in addition to the
IDBObjectStore.add request's success event, because the
transaction may still fail after the success event fires. In other words, the success
event is only triggered when the transaction has been successfully queued.

The add method is an insert only method. If a
record already exists in the object store with the key parameter as its
key, then an error ConstraintError event is fired on the returned request
object. For updating existing records, you should use the
method instead.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreAdd.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is the key for the new record.

IDBObjectStoreIndex.summary:
The index() method of the
interface opens a named index in the current object store, after which it can be used
to, for example, return a series of records sorted by that index using a cursor.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreIndex.returns: An object for accessing the index.

IDBObjectStoreClear.summary:
The clear() method of the
interface creates and immediately returns an object, and
clears this object store in a separate thread. This is for deleting all the current
data out of an object store.

remarks.para:
Clearing an object store consists of removing all records from the object store and
removing all records in indexes that reference the object store. To remove only some of
the records in a store, use passing a key
or .

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreClear.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is undefined.

IDBObjectStoreIndexNames.summary:
The indexNames read-only property of the
interface returns a list of the names of indexes on objects
in this object store.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:

IDBObjectStoreDeleteIndex.summary:
The deleteIndex() method of the
interface destroys the index with the specified name in
the connected database, used during a version upgrade.

remarks.para:
Note that this method must be called only from a VersionChange transaction
mode callback. Note that this method synchronously modifies the
property.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreGetAllKeys.summary:
The getAllKeys() method of the
interface returns an object retrieves record keys for all
objects in the object store matching the specified parameter or all objects in the
store if no parameters are given.

remarks.para:
If a value is successfully found, then a structured clone of it is created and set as
the result of the request object.
This method produces the same result for:

To tell these situations apart, you need to call the
method with the same key. That
method provides a cursor if the record exists, and no cursor if it does not.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreGetAllKeys.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is an {{jsxref("Array")}} of the keys for all records matching the given query, up to the value of count, if count was supplied.

IDBObjectStoreGet.summary:
The get() method of the
interface returns an object, and, in a separate thread,
returns the object selected by the specified key. This is for retrieving
specific records from an object store.

remarks.para:
If a value is successfully found, then a structured clone of it is created and set as
the result of the
request object.

blockquote.para:
This method produces the same result for: a) a record that doesn't exist in the database and b) a record that has an undefined value.
To tell these situations apart, call the openCursor() method with the same key. That method provides a cursor if the record exists, and no cursor if it does not.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreGet.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is the value of the first record matching the given key or key range.

IDBObjectStoreDelete.summary:
The delete() method of the
interface returns an object,
and, in a separate thread, deletes the specified record or records.

remarks.para:
Either a key or an can be passed, allowing one or multiple
records to be deleted from a store. To delete all records in a store, use
.

Bear in mind that if you are using a , you can use
the method to more efficiently delete the current
record â€” without having to explicitly look up the record's key.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreDelete.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is undefined.

IDBObjectStoreCreateIndex.summary:
The createIndex() method of the
interface creates and returns a new
object in the connected database. It creates a new
field/column defining a new data point for each database record to contain.

remarks.para:
Note that this method must be called only from a VersionChange transaction
mode callback.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreCreateIndex.returns: An object: the newly created index.

IDBObjectStoreTransaction.summary:
The transaction read-only property of the
interface returns the transaction object to which this
object store belongs.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:

IDBObjectStoreCount.summary:
The count() method of the
interface returns an object, and, in a separate thread,
returns the total number of records that match the provided key or
. If no arguments are provided, it returns the total number
of records in the store.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreCount.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is the number of records that match the given query.

IDBObjectStoreOpenCursor.summary:
The openCursor() method of the
interface returns an object,
and, in a separate thread, returns a new object.
Used for iterating through an object store with a cursor.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:

IDBObjectStoreOpenKeyCursor.summary:
The openKeyCursor() method of the
interface returns an object
whose result will be set to an that can be used to iterate
through matching results. Used for iterating through the keys of an object store with
a cursor.

remarks.para:
To determine if the add operation has completed successfully, listen for the
results's success event.

IDBObjectStoreName.summary:
The name property of the
interface indicates the name of this object store.

IDBObjectStoreAutoIncrement.summary:
The autoIncrement read-only property of the
interface returns the value of the auto increment flag
for this object store.

remarks.para: Note that every object store has its own separate auto increment counter.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStoreAutoIncrement.value:
A boolean value:
ValueMeaning
trueThe object store auto increments.
falseThe object store does not auto increment.

IDBObjectStoreKeyPath.summary:
The keyPath read-only property of the
interface returns the key path of this object store.

remarks.para:
If this property is null, the application must provide a key for each modification
operation.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:

IDBObjectStorePut.summary: The put() method of the interface updates a given record in a database, or inserts a new record if the given item does not already exist.

remarks.para: It returns an object, and, in a separate thread, creates a structured clone of the value and stores the cloned value in the object store. This is for adding new records, or updating existing records in an object store when the transaction's mode is readwrite. If the record is successfully stored, then a success event is fired on the returned request object with the result set to the key for the stored record, and the transaction set to the transaction in which this object store is opened.

The put method is an update or insert method.
See the method for an insert only method.

Bear in mind that if you have a to the record you
want to update, updating it with is preferable to
using IDBObjectStore.put(). Doing so makes it clear that an existing
record will be updated, instead of a new record being inserted.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBObjectStorePut.returns: An object on which subsequent events related to this operation are fired.If the operation is successful, the value of the request's property is the key for the new or updated record.
